In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Here is the Julia code snippet which solves your problem:

```julia
function wrap_string(input_string::String, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(input_string, " ")
    line_length = 0
    result = ""
    for word in words
        if line_length + length(word) + 1 > text_width
            result *= "\n"
            line_length = 0
        elseif !isempty(result)
            result *= " "
        end
        line_length += length(word)+1
        result *= word
    end
    return result
end

# Example usage:
input_string = "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua."
println(wrap_string(input_string))
```

This function works by iterating over the words in the input string and adding them to the result string, with a new line character inserted after each word. The `line_length` variable is used to keep track of how many characters have been added to the current line. When this limit (the `text_width`) would be exceeded, a newline is inserted.
